SubTopics: Determine the main idea of a text; recount the key details and explain how they support the main idea.
Content: What is the most likely reason the author includes the example of Stan Munro’s toothpick structure holding up a desk?

A.Choice: to show that toothpick structures can be beautiful

Key.Rationale: Although Munro’s structures may be beautiful, there is no evidence to support that this is why he includes the fact about the desk.

B.Choice: to show that toothpick structures can be tiny

Key.Rationale: Although some structures may be tiny, Munro’s structures are actually quite large.

C.Choice: to show that toothpick structures can be dangerous

Key.Rationale: Although transporting the structures may be dangerous, there is no evidence that toothpick structures themselves are dangerous.

D.Choice: to show that toothpick structures can be strong

Key.Rationale: This option shows that Stan Munro’s construction was very strong.

SubTopics: Describe the relationship between a series of historical events, scientific ideas or concepts, or steps in technical procedures in a text, using language that pertains to time, sequence, and cause/effect.
Content: This question has two parts. Answer Part One and then answer Part Two.
How did dropping part of a completed structure affect Munro’s process?

A.Choice: Munro chose to use smaller scales for his models.

Key.Rationale: Although Munro builds his structures to be smaller than the original structures on which they are based, there is no evidence that his dropping part of a completed structure caused him to use smaller scales.

B.Choice: Munro took extra steps to reduce the chances of breaking his work.

Key.Rationale: Munro implemented changes to avoid breaking another one of his structures.

C.Choice: Munro increased the strength of his models by using certain designs.

Key.Rationale: Although Munro uses a specific design for each structure, there is no evidence that he increased the strength of his models as a result of his dropping part of his buildings.

D.Choice: Munro made changes to the materials he uses for construction.

Key.Rationale: There is no evidence to support the idea that Munro changed the materials he uses in his constructions

Content: Which evidence from the passage supports the answer in Part One? Choose TWO answers.

A.Choice: “Tons of bubble wrap; tuck in your shirt and your shoelaces so you don’t trip.”

Key.Rationale: This option shows how Munro instituted changes in his actions to avoid accidents in the future.

B.Choice: “The really big structures are built in pieces to assemble on-site . . .”

Key.Rationale: This option shows how Munro instituted changes in his actions to avoid accidents in the future.
Although Munro does use algebra to create his designs, this option does not show how Munro reduced the chances of breaking his work.

D.Choice: “The triangle is considered the strongest architectural structure.”

Key.Rationale: This option does not support how Munro reduced the chances of breaking his work.

SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 3 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: Read the sentence from the passage.
:ibox:I used to be a reporter, which is a fine [profession], but I think this is more fun.
What does the word “profession” mean as used in the passage?

Key.Rationale: The word “profession” means “career.” The phrase “used to be a reporter” provides context for the correct answer.
This option does not convey the meaning of the word “profession.”
This option does not convey the meaning of the word “profession.”
This option does not convey the meaning of the word “profession.”

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Describe the logical connection between particular sentences and paragraphs to support specific points in a text (e.g., comparison, cause/effect, first/second/third in a sequence).
Content: Read the sentences from the passage.

:ibox:Q: What’s your favorite building?

A: The next one.
What does Stan Munro’s answer show about him?

A.Choice: that he does not like any of his buildings

Key.Rationale: Munro states, “I love this job!”

B.Choice: that he wants to end the interview

Key.Rationale: There is no textual evidence that Munro wants to end the interview.

C.Choice: that he likes creating new buildings

Key.Rationale: This option shows Munro’s attitude of being enthusiastic for future projects.

D.Choice: that he wants a different interview question

Key.Rationale: There is no textual evidence to support that Munro wants a different interview question.

SubTopics: Explain the point of view from which a text is written.
Content: From whose point of view is the passage written?

Key.Rationale: The passage is an interview; questions from an interviewer and answers from Munro are provided.

B.Choice: someone who works for Stan Munro

Key.Rationale: There is no evidence that the interviewer works for Munro.
Although Munro’s teacher is mentioned in the passage, the interviewer is not Munro’s teacher.
The passage is an interview in which someone asks questions and then Munro answers them.

SubTopics: Describe the relationship between a series of historical events, scientific ideas or concepts, or steps in technical procedures in a text, using language that pertains to time, sequence, and cause/effect.
Content: Based on the passage, what should be considered when designing a toothpick structure? Use information from the passage to support your answer.

SubTopics: Choose words and phrases for effect.
Content: Read the sentence.
:ibox:The horse ran across the field.
Which revision of the sentence uses the most descriptive details?

A.Choice: The pretty horse went across the large field.

Key.Rationale: The words “pretty” and “went” are not as descriptive as the words used in the key.

B.Choice: The horse quickly moved farther away in the field.

Key.Rationale: The words “moved farther away” are not as descriptive as the words used in the key.

C.Choice: The beautiful brown horse raced across the grassy field.

Key.Rationale: The words “beautiful,” “brown,” “raced,” and “grassy” provide descriptive details that evoke visual imagery for the reader.

D.Choice: The horse jogged quickly to a different part of the big field.

Key.Rationale: The words “jogged quickly” are not as descriptive as the words used in the key.

SubTopics: Form and use regular and irregular plural nouns.
Content: Read the sentence.
:ibox:Yesterday, Tony went to the bakery and bought two ______ of bread.
Which word correctly completes the sentence?

Key.Rationale: This option incorrectly uses the spelling rule to create the plural form.
This option incorrectly uses the spelling rule to create the plural form.
This option incorrectly uses the spelling rule to create the plural form.
This option applies the rule of changing the “f” in nouns ending in “f” to “ves” to create the plural form.

SubTopics: Produce simple, compound, and complex sentences.
Content: Read the sentences.

:ibox:Tess helped her mom plant flowers.

The flowers looked beautiful in the garden.
Choose the BEST way to write the sentences as a complex sentence without changing the meaning.

A.Choice: Tess helped her mom plant flowers, which looked beautiful in the garden.

Key.Rationale: This option creates a complex sentence without changing the meaning of the two original sentences.

B.Choice: Since Tess helped her mom plant flowers, they looked beautiful in the garden.

Key.Rationale: The use of the words “since” indicate a conditional relationship that is not present in the original sentences.

C.Choice: When the flowers in the garden looked beautiful, Tess helped her mom plant them.

Key.Rationale: The use of the words “when” indicate a conditional relationship that is not present in the original sentences.

D.Choice: Although the flowers looked beautiful in the garden, Tess helped her mom plant them.

Key.Rationale: The word “although” indicates an oppositional relationship that is not present in the original sentences.

SubTopics: Use conventional spelling for high-frequency and other studied words and for adding suffixes to base words (e.g., sitting, smiled, cries, happiness).
Content: Which emphasized word is spelled incorrectly?

A.Choice: I visit my grandpa [whenever] I can.

Key.Rationale: This option is spelled correctly.

B.Choice: It was finally time to [decorate] the cake.

Key.Rationale: This option is spelled correctly.

C.Choice: The cat [leeped] over the tall wooden fence.

Key.Rationale: “Leeped” should be spelled as “leaped.”

D.Choice: My brother and I enjoy going on [adventures] together.

Key.Rationale: This option is spelled correctly.
